p: A nanoemulsion is a drug delivery system consisting of emulsified oil and water, with an average droplet size of 5–200 nm [ 12]. It is considered a highly kinetically stable system that prevents creaming, flocculation, and aggregation from occurring [ 13, 14]. It can deliver both hydrophilic and lipophilic drug agents and can be administered via different routes, such as topical, oral, and parenteral routes [ 15]. An emulsion is a compound composed of at least two immiscible liquid phases, one of which is distributed into the other as globules. It is an effective dosage type for drugs with low water-solubility [ 16, 17]. However, emulsions have certain limitations because of some parameters, such as pH, temperature, and stability. The emulsions may also be subjected to creaming, coalescence, and flocculation [ 18].
